Development of an educational virtual transmission electron microscope laboratory
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 17 October 2014

Development of an educational virtual transmission electron microscope laboratory

  • Wernhuar Tarng1,
  • Chi-Fen Tsai1,
  • Chih-Ming Lin2,
  • Chi-Young Lee3 &
  • Hsin-Hun Liou4 

Virtual Reality volume 19, pages33–44(2015)Cite this article

  • 472 Accesses

  • 5 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

In recent years, many high-tech instruments have been developed to investigate the nanostructures of materials. For example, the transmission electron microscope (TEM) is capable of imaging at a significantly higher resolution than light microscopes, enabling scientists to examine the very fine detail of materials even as small as a single column of atoms. It can also be used as a diffractometer to obtain the scattering pattern of a material for analysis of its 3D crystal structure. However, the TEM is a very expensive apparatus such that many students do not have a chance to operate it personally, thus causing the difficulty of understanding its principle and operating procedure. In this study, a virtual TEM laboratory has been developed to help students learn how to analyze the 3D crystal structures of different materials such as diamond, graphite, and anatase according to their diffraction patterns. A teaching experiment was conducted to study the learning effectiveness of using the virtual TEM laboratory for educational applications. The results showed that the virtual TEM laboratory could improve students’ learning motivation and achievement in nanostructure analysis.

Introduction

Feynman (1960), the father of nanotechnology, proposed “There’s Plenty of Room at the Bottom” at a meeting of American Physical Society. He predicted that the development of technology will move forward down to the microscale. These were the words of wisdom in nanotechnology, and they had gradually become well known in 1990. In the last two decades, the advanced countries fully supported the research and development of nanotechnology, which appears as the new hope of economy in the twenty-first century. Nanotechnology changes the industrial structure and human lifestyle and is therefore considered as the fourth industrial revolution. Some people even predict that its impact on human life is greater than the influence of information technology and semiconductor industry.

Considering the importance of nanotechnology, National Science Council (NSC) of Taiwan started the National Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Program (NNNP), an esteemed scientific research venture initiated in 2003. It was aimed at establishing a nanotechnology personnel training mechanism for the promotion and development of local nanotechnology industry. To foster the training mechanism at all levels in the country, NSC launched the National Nanoscience Training Project (NNTP) to reinforce nanotechnology education. Its goal was to enhance the literacy of nanotechnology for school teachers, K12 students, and the general public.

With the rapid development of nanotechnology and the semiconductor industry, scientists now are able to explore nanomaterials at the atomic level. In order to observe materials at such a small scale, a series of new laboratory equipment has been developed. Recently, several high-resolution microscopes such as the atomic force microscope (Tsai et al. 2007), the transmission electron microscope (Neogy et al. 2006), and the magnetic force microscope (Rugar et al. 1990) were created to examine the nanostructures of different materials.

The TEM was first built by Max Knoll and Ernst Ruska in 1931. Two years later, they developed the first TEM with resolution greater than that of light microscopes, which was first commercialized in 1939. The TEM is capable of imaging at a significantly higher resolution, enabling scientists to examine the fine detail of materials even as small as a single column of atoms. The TEM is a useful analysis tool in a range of scientific fields, in both physical and biological sciences, and its applications include cancer research, virology, materials science as well as pollution, nanotechnology, and semiconductor research.

The TEM can also be used as a diffractometer to obtain the diffraction patterns of materials for the analysis of their 3D crystal structures by emitting an accelerated and concentrated electron beam at an extremely thin sample. When the electrons collide with the atoms in the sample and change their directions, the scattering angles are related to the density and thickness of the sample. An image of varied illumination by the diffracted electrons called the diffraction pattern is formed to show the information about the 3D crystal structures of materials. Thus, the TEM can also be used as an important tool in material identification (Chen 2008).

Theoretically, the maximum resolution that one can obtain using a light microscope is limited by the wavelength of the photons being used to examine the sample and the numerical aperture of the system. In comparison to the visible light source of optical microscopy, the light source of TEM comes from the hot electrons emitted under high voltages. Because the wavelength of these hot electrons is extremely short, they can be magnified tens of thousands of times by the effect of electric field lens. Therefore, the resolution of a TEM is much higher than that of an optical microscopy. At smaller magnifications, the contrast TEM image is caused by the absorption of electrons in the material, according to its thickness and composition. At higher magnifications, the intensity of the image is modulated by complex wave interactions and thus expert analysis is required. The imaging principle of diffraction patterns by the TEM electron beam will obey Bragg’s Law (Nave 2008), and its wavelength is shorter and easier to concentrate within a diameter of 10 nm or less. As a result, it is possible to display the structure and orientation of crystals for better observation. The TEM is a useful tool for measurement and analysis at a very small scale, and, due to the continual breakthrough, it can now be used to examine the 3D crystal structures at nano and atomic levels (Chen 2012).

Nanostructure analysis is very important for understanding the formation of different materials. When teaching how to use the TEM to analyze the crystal structures without using real equipment, the instructors have to explain the principles involved in the TEM first and then they often use a laser pointer to simulate the electron beam to explain the diffraction phenomenon. They may also ask students to calculate the width of raster according to diffraction patterns. This way of teaching only provides a simple simulation, and students may not understand how to operate a real TEM in the laboratory to examine the crystal structures of samples. Even with real equipment, only a small number of students can use it to conduct experiments. Lacking for theoretical and practical foundation, it is difficult for them to obtain correct results due to unfamiliar with the principles and operating procedures of the TEM.

Virtual reality (VR) is a technology to create interactive environments for simulating the real world through one’s sense organs. The users can see, hear and even feel in the created scenes as if situated in the real world, and even interact with the objects in the virtual scenes. The most commonly used VR technique is the 3D visual simulation, allowing users to interact with others in the virtual world by wearing stereo glasses or the head-mounted display (HMD) to enhance their initiative, operability, and sensitivity (Kim 2005). A few studies suggested the use of VR to improve students’ learning interest and motivation as well as the ability and positive attitudes toward learning (Deaton et al. 2006; Bossard et al. 2008; Annett and Bischof 2010). The scientific researchers are able to exploit VR for visualizing scientific data (Yannier et al. 2008) and modeling complex engineering and medical systems (Burdea and Coiffet 2003). In addition, VR allows educators to place their students in an instructional environment which is otherwise difficult or impossible to achieve (Tarng et al. 2011, 2012, 2014).

As the advance of information technology, mobile devices such as smart phones and tablet PCs are integrated into modern instructional applications. As a result, learning activities are no longer confined to classroom teaching, and they can be done anytime and anywhere by using any devices to achieve the goal of ubiquitous learning (Harris 2001). Mobile learning refers to any types of learning which may take place when a learner is on the move or can move to a new place and still remain connected to online learning resources through wireless networks. Recently, a large number of mobile devices with powerful sensors such as GPS, electronic compass, and 3-axis accelerometers can provide the information of position, time, direction, acceleration, and so on to support the design of simulation software for applications in different areas of education. In this study, the virtual TEM laboratory is implemented as an application for execution on tablet PCs to achieve the goal of learning how to use the TEM easily and with more fun.

Situated learning was first proposed by Brown et al. (1989) and its concept is to simulate a realistic environment to provide learners with learning situations for exploring knowledge by the interaction with real or created teaching materials. The learning activity is designed for learners to participate in the process of learning, introspection, investigation, and feedback, and the objective is to adaptively develop suitable knowledge and ability for them to apply in the future. Situated learning emphasizes the reality of learning activities, and it is similar to “Learning by Doing” (Dewey 1938) and “Learning from Experiences” (Kolb 1984). The emergence of situated learning attracted a number of related theories and research, such as constructivism, anchored instruction, and cognitive apprenticeship, and they were applied in various teaching models (Wang 2009). This study used the theory of situated learning to develop a virtual TEM laboratory, which allows students to actively explore and conduct virtual experiments to acquire meaningful knowledge for future applications. The goal is for students to become familiar with the procedure of using a TEM to analyze the 3D crystal structures of materials.

A virtual TEM laboratory has been developed in this study to support the NNTP, and the objective is to promote the related knowledge of nanotechnology to K12 science education as well as general teaching in colleges. The high interaction and instant feedback of the virtual TEM laboratory allow students to become familiar with the principles and operational procedures of TEM, and it will achieve the following learning objectives:

  • Recognize the basic components and major functions of TEM.

  • Familiarize with the principles and operating procedures of TEM.

  • Understand the relationship between samples’ 3D crystal structures and their diffraction patterns.

  • Increase the interest of students in analyzing the nanostructures of materials.

When using the virtual TEM laboratory as a teaching tool, instructors may first introduce the principles of TEM and then ask students to use the virtual TEM laboratory to conduct some experiments. According to the system direction, students can select a sample and put into the TEM to observe its diffraction pattern and the crystal structure. If they make any mistake during operation, the system will provide a verbal or textual reminder. After all tasks have been completed, the students can take the online test to evaluate their learning achievements.

This study used the innovative learning technology to enhance students’ scientific literacy, research skills, and problem-solving ability. Combining virtual reality with situated learning and mobile devices, the virtual TEM laboratory was designed to achieve the goal of learning nanostructure analysis. Students can understand the principles of TEM through interactive operation and instant feedback and finally become familiar with the operating procedures via repeated practices. A teaching experiment was conducted in this study to investigate if the virtual TEM laboratory could enhance students’ learning achievements as well as their learning interest and motivation.

System design

The basic structure of TEM is primarily made up of an electron gun and several electron lenses (Williams and Carter 1996). The electron lenses include the condenser lens, objective lens, intermediate lens, and projective lens; the electron gun is mainly composed of a cathode and an anode; the cathode is the electron emission source and the anode is used to accelerate electrons. The resolution of TEM is mainly related to the acceleration voltage of electrons and aberration, and it is limited by electron source geometry and brightness as well as the chromatic aberrations in the objective lens system. A higher acceleration voltage produces a shorter wavelength and thus a better resolution. As the kinetic energy of electrons increases, the ability of electron beam to penetrate the sample also increases (Jin et al. 2012). When using the TEM to test samples, the diffracted electrons form the bright or dark field images which can be combined with the diffraction patterns for observing the samples’ crystal structures.

The development environment of the virtual TEM laboratory is Microsoft Windows 7 using the design tools ShiVa3D (2013), 3ds Max (2013) and Photoshop. ShiVa3D is a platform for 3D real-time development, and it allows designers to develop first-person games, platform games, and massive online multiplayer role-play games. It can also be used to develop applications on mobile devices using simple user interface API. ShiVa3D’s Authoring Tool is the software to export the design of ShiVa3D for publication on Windows, Mac, Linux, iPhone, iPad, Android, and Internet using the plug-in software of Android SDK/NDK, Cygwin, and Apache Ant. After the completion of system design, ShiVa3D’s Authoring Tool is used to convert it into the installation file published on Google Play for users to download.

This study combined the VR technology with the sensor functions of mobile devices to develop a virtual TEM laboratory to help students learn how to analyze the 3D crystal structures of different materials according to diffraction patterns. To enable observation from different angles, this study used the functions of electronic compass and 3-axis accelerometers in mobile devices to control the camera’s angle and the moving direction in the virtual TEM laboratory. To provide a more in-depth and convenient way of observation, the first-person camera angle was used to mimic the user’s visual effect. Students can use the touch screen and motion-sensing control to observe and operate the apparatus to better understand its principle and operating procedure. The physical operation provides them with an immersive and interactive way of observation.

The system modules of the virtual TEM laboratory include camera and touch-screen controllers, API programs for user interface control and online test. The system was designed by following the guidelines of situated learning for conducting virtual experiments to observe the 3D crystal structure of materials. It can be operated interactively using the touch screen on mobile devices such as smart phones and tablet PCs.

User interface control

ShiVa3D provides three event handlers, i.e., onMouseButtonDown, onMouseMove, and onMouseButtonUp, for designing the user interface of touch-screen control. For example, the user can move a sample to the sample holder or rotate its 3D crystal model by using the touch screen. If the user wants to change scene by using the touch screen, the designer can use AIModel Editor to create a variable for switching on/off a virtual scene, and it can also be used to determine whether the user is still in the scene or not. The AIModel Editor allows the designer to edit the behavior of created models such as variables, functions, states, and handlers. ShiVa3D also provides many user interface controllers, such as the button selection and camera control. In the virtual scene, the camera plays the role of the user’s eyes and its viewing angle is controlled by the operation of touch screen. The designer can use rotateTo and translateTo to control the rotation and movement of the camera.

Virtual TEM model

In this study, the virtual TEM model was developed according to the 200 kV field emission TEM (Fig. 1) of the Nano-Microscopy Laboratory, Tamkang University. This study used the software 3ds Max to develop the TEM and samples’ 3D crystal models and used Photoshop to create the texture images required for the virtual TEM laboratory. Finally, the VR software ShiVa3D was used to design the user interface and control programs to simulate the operating procedures of TEM.

Manipulation of the electron beam in the TEM is performed using two physical effects. The interaction of electrons with a magnetic field will cause them to move based on the right hand rule, allowing electromagnets to manipulate the electron beam. The magnetic lens is designed using magnetic fields to produce variable focusing power, and its shape is originated due to the distribution of magnetic flux. In addition, electrostatic fields are used to deflect the electrons through a constant angle. The shift of beam path in the TEM is done by combining two deflections in opposing directions with a small gap. Due to these two effects, the control over the beam path is possible for its operation in the TEM (Fig. 2). When electrons pass through the sample, they are diffracted due to the atoms in the crystal. The distance between atoms is about 0.1 nm which becomes the raster of electron wave. The interference between the scattered electrons through the raster will obey the Bragg’s law, Lλ/d = x, where L is the distance between the sample and fluorescent screen, λ is the wave length of electrons, d is the raster distance, and x is the distance between diffraction points.

Sample holder model

This study used the software 3ds Max to develop the sample holder model and then used Photoshop to create the required texture images (Fig. 3). The most common sample holder is the side-entry holder (the one used in the virtual TEM laboratory) where the specimen is placed near the tip of a long metal (brass or stainless steel) rod, with the specimen placed flat in a small bore.

Crystal structure model

The software Diamond (Chou et al. 2012) was used to provide the 3D crystal structural information for various samples. For example, the distances of atoms and angles between planes and/or lines can be measured. This study used 3ds Max and the above information to develop the crystal structures of diamond, graphite, and titanium dioxide (Fig. 4). The software ShiVa3D was used to import the models from 3ds Max to combine with the virtual TEM laboratory for users to conduct experiments to enhance their knowledge about 3D crystal structures of various samples.

When designing the corresponding relation between the crystal structure and diffraction pattern for a sample, the software Diamond was used to obtain the information about the sample’s crystal structure. After that, the software CaRine Crystallography (2013) was used to simulate the diffraction patterns in different zone axes. Finally, Photoshop was used to set the illumination at the positions of atoms to simulate the diffraction patterns obtained by using the TEM in the directions of different zone axes.

Operating procedure

The virtual TEM laboratory is designed as an app for execution on mobile devices. The users can enter the virtual TEM laboratory, and the system direction will guide them to open the task checklist to perform virtual experiments. In the virtual TEM laboratory, there are three operable objects for selection: (1) the TEM, (2) the sample holder, and (3) the samples (diamond, graphite, and anatase). The major operating steps of the virtual TEM laboratory are described in the following:

  • When the app is activated, the users can read the introduction page first, which shows the learning objectives as well as the principles and operating procedure of the TEM.

  • After entering the virtual TEM laboratory, the users can open the task checklist to know the tasks to be completed.

  • When the users click the TEM equipment, they will learn about the principles of TEM and the major functions of its components.

  • The users can manipulate the sample holder to know its structure and functions, and they can learn to attach the sample to it and insert into the TEM for observation.

  • The users can select any samples on the table, i.e., diamond, graphite, and anatase, to perform observation. By rotating the sample’s crystal model and observing its diffraction pattern, they can learn about the sample’s crystal structure and its chemical and physical characteristics.

  • The users can take the online test to evaluate how much they have learned after completing the assigned tasks.

Virtual TEM laboratory

In the virtual TEM laboratory, the users can slide their fingers on the touch screen to change the perspective, enabling them to see and operate each component of the TEM easily. The system direction will remind the users to click the triangle on the left to open the task checklist first (Fig. 5), and it can also direct them to click any uncompleted tasks. There are six items on the checklist, i.e., (1) familiar with TEM, (2) familiar with the sample holder, (3) the diamond sample, (4) the graphite sample, (5) the titanium dioxide sample, and (6) online test. After clicking a task, an explanatory window is opened to show the requirement for the task, accompanied by a verbal prompt guiding them to complete the task. When the task checklist is opened, the users can still change the perspective by sliding their fingers on the screen, which makes it easy to see every piece of equipment in the laboratory. Users can click the triangle of the task checklist again to close it, or they can select a sample in the laboratory to carry out the observation. If the users select the task “Online Test” before all the other tasks have been completed, a warning message will pop up to remind that they have not completed the specified tasks yet and are therefore unable to take the test temporarily.

Sample holder

When the users click the virtual TEM in the laboratory, the learning contents about the principles of TEM and the introduction of operating procedures will be displayed. The users can click the keywords highlighted in red to learn about the extended knowledge or click “Next” to read the next page. The users can complete the task by inserting samples into the TEM for observing the diffraction patterns according to the verbal prompts and the reminder (flashing outlines of the sample box) to manipulate the samples (Fig. 6).

The task of testing a sample can be divided into the following three steps:

  • Click the sample box to place the sample on the sample holder.

  • Click the sample holder to insert the sample holder into the TEM.

  • Click the computer screen to examine the sample’s crystal structure and display its diffraction pattern.

When the user clicks the sample holder on the table, the viewing direction will gradually move toward it and an introduction to the sample holder will be displayed (Fig. 7). Usually, the insertion procedure for side-entry TEM sample holders requires the rotation of the sample to trigger microswitches that initiate evacuation of the airlock before the sample is inserted into the TEM column. The users can drag and rotate the sample holder with their fingers to obtain a better view of its structure. They can click the button at the upright corner to return to the laboratory. After that, the users can attach the sample for observation to the sample holder and insert it into the TEM to conduct the observation.

Observing samples

There are three types of samples in the virtual TEM laboratory, i.e., diamond, graphite, and anatase. After selecting the sample for observation, the camera’s perspective is switched to the sample and a window with the 3D crystal structure of the sample will pop up (Fig. 8). Following the prompt, the users can slide their fingers on the screen to rotate the crystal model to better understand its structure. After that, they can return to the TEM laboratory or go one step further to analyze the crystal structures according to diffraction patterns.

Diffraction pattern

The monitor will display the diffraction pattern of the sample after the scan has been completed. Figures 9, 10, and 11 show the diffraction patterns and the crystal structures for the samples of diamond, graphite, and anatase. In these figures, the left part shows the crystal structure of the sample; the central part displays the 3D crystal structure of the sample; the right part is the diffraction pattern for the corresponding zone axis. Users can select the zone axis to observe the sample’s 3D crystal structure and its diffraction pattern from different angles. For each sample, this study has created diffraction patterns in seven axes: 〈001〉, 〈010〉, 〈100〉, 〈011〉, 〈101〉, 〈110〉, and 〈111〉. For example, 〈100〉 stands for the x axis and 〈010〉 means the y axis.

Online test

When the users have completed the first five tasks on the task checklist, the system will request them to take the online test to know how well they have learned. By clicking “Online Test”, the system will display the test item for the users to select the answer. For example, the question in Fig. 12 shows: “When conducting the TEM experiment, the sample and electron gun must be kept in which of the following conditions?” Users can select the answer in the prompt box on the left hand side. If the users select (A): Vacuum, the system will echo “You are right.” and move to the next test item; if they select the wrong answer, the system will show the correct answer and explain the reason.

Teaching experiment

A teaching experiment was performed to evaluate the effectiveness of using the virtual TEM laboratory in teaching nanostructure analysis. A questionnaire survey was also conducted to investigate the attitudes of students after using the virtual TEM laboratory. This study randomly selected 38 students from the department of applied science in a university at Hsinchu, Taiwan, as the experimental samples, who were divided into the control group (17 students) and experimental group A (21 students). The control group was given a lecture and watched an instructional video showing the experimental process of using the real TEM to test a sample. The experimental group A was given the same lecture and used the virtual TEM laboratory as a learning tool. To include the samples of different ages, this study taught the 36 participants (mostly high school students) at a science camp to use the virtual TEM laboratory (Fig. 13) and they were used as the experimental group B, allowing comparison of learning achievements between users of different ages.

This study adopted a nonequivalent pretest–posttest design involving different groups to investigate whether there was a significant difference between the learning achievements of different groups. Before teaching activities, all students were asked to take a pretest for the background knowledge of TEM. After the teaching activities, they took the posttest and the experimental groups also filled out a questionnaire. To realize the difference between the two teaching methods, the control group was asked to use the virtual TEM laboratory for 30 min at the end and then fill out an open-ended questionnaire. The variables in the teaching experiment are shown in Table 1, and the flowchart of the teaching experiment is shown in Fig. 14.

Research tools

The research tools used in this study include the virtual TEM laboratory, the TEM instructional video, achievement test, and questionnaire survey, which are described in the following:

The virtual TEM laboratory

The virtual TEM laboratory is an app for execution on mobile devices, and its contents were based on TEM experiments for analyzing the crystal structures of materials. The system was installed on tablet PCs and used by students in the experimental groups.

Instructional video

The instructional video used by the control group was filmed by experts who conducted an experiment using a real TEM to observe samples in the Nano-Microscopy Laboratory at Tamkang University, Taipei. The process of the experiment included (1) putting the sample on the holder, (2) alignment of the TEM for basic observation, (3) taking a picture in bright-field mode condition, (4) turning to diffraction mode to get one ring pattern, (5) selecting one diffraction spot to take one dark field pattern, and (6) analyzing the diffraction patterns.

Achievement test

The achievement test (including the pretest and posttest) used by this study contained 20 test items which were designed based on the research goal, teaching objectives, and TEM learning contents. They were revised according to the suggestions of experts and science teachers.

Questionnaire survey

The questionnaire survey used in this study was a system satisfaction survey according to users’ experiences, and it was designed based on the discussion of experts and science teachers. The questionnaire contained 19 questions (5 questions in learning contents, 6 questions in interface design, and 8 questions in operating experiences). This study adopted Likert’s 5-point scale (scoring: 5 = strongly agree; 4 = agree; 3 = neutral; 2 = disagree; 1 = strongly disagree) to measure the attitudes of students after using the system. The statistical software SPSS was used to perform a reliability analysis, and the value of Cronbach’s alpha was calculated as 0.95, showing the results had met the standard of high reliability.

Learning achievement analysis

In the teaching experiment, the experimental groups A and B used the virtual TEM laboratory and the control group watched a TEM instructional video for learning. An ANCOVA was conducted to see whether there was a significant difference in learning effectiveness among the three groups. The statistical software SPSS was used to analyze the test results (Table 2). This study used a Levene’s test to compare the pretest results to see if any significant differences about the background knowledge of nanostructure analysis existed among these groups; the results show that F = 1.328 and P = 0.272 > 0.05 (significant standard), indicating no significant difference and their background knowledge was about the same.

This study used a paired sample T test to perform a statistical analysis (Table 3) on the pretest and posttest for the control group and experimental groups A and B. For the control group, the T value is 5.13 and the significance P < 0.05, indicating the lecture and instructional video is effective to enhance the control group’s learning achievement. For the experimental group A, the T value is 9.91; for the experimental group B, the T value is 5.50. For both experimental group A and B, the significance P < 0.05, indicating the lecture and the virtual TEM laboratory can also enhance their learning achievements.

Before conducting an ANCOVA, the assumptions for the homogeneity of variance and within-group regression coefficients have to be satisfied. The statistical results for the above analysis are described in the following:

Homogeneity of variance

This study used a Levene’s test to verify whether there was homogeneity of variance in the three groups. According to the test results, the value of F = 0.163 and the significance P = 0.004 < 0.05, indicating the assumption for homogeneity of variance was not satisfied. A further analysis revealed that it was caused by the experimental group B, which consisted of high school students with less knowledge about the TEM and crystal structures of materials. After excluding the experimental group B; the analysis was carried out again by comparing the control group and the experimental group A only. The results show that F = 0.163 and the significance P = 0.689 > 0.05 and thus the assumption for the homogeneity of variance is satisfied now.

Homogeneity of within-group regression coefficients

Before the ANCOVA, the test for homogeneity of within-group regression coefficients must be carried out for the control group and experimental group A. The results show that F = 1.739 and P = 0.196 > 0.05, which is less than the standard of significance. As a result, the dependent variables and covariance are not influenced by the independent variable and the assumption is satisfied, so the ANCOVA can be continued.

ANCOVA results

This study used an ANCOVA to compare the difference in learning achievements between the control group and the experimental group A (Table 4). After excluding the effect of covariance and dependent variables, the impact of independent variable (the teaching method) is obtained as F = 13.66 and P = 0.001 < 0.05. A significant difference exists between the learning achievements of control group and experimental group A, and the learning achievement of the latter is higher than that of the former. In other words, the virtual TEM laboratory is more effective than the TEM instructional video for enhancing the learning achievement.

Questionnaire results

This study carried out a statistical analysis on questionnaire results by the experimental group A and B as a system satisfaction survey. A further comparison of significant differences in evaluation items between these two groups was also conducted to find out the items with distinct results due to different-age users.

Learning contents

This section investigated users’ satisfaction about the learning contents of the virtual TEM laboratory. Most students thought they could understand the textual explanations in the virtual TEM laboratory, and the images in the virtual TEM laboratory were clear. They agreed that the virtual TEM laboratory provided adequate prompts, and its contents taught them the knowledge about samples’ crystal structures. Also, the 3D crystal models allowed them to understand the nanostructures of different samples. The statistical results revealed that the average score of “Learning Contents” is 4.37 for the experimental group A and is 4.15 for the experimental group B. For each evaluation item, a comparison between the scores given by the two groups is done by the Levene’s test, and the result shows that the P value is higher than the standard of significant. Therefore, there is no significant difference for the two groups in their attitudes regarding learning contents.

Interface design

This section investigates users’ satisfaction toward interface design. Most students considered the operation of virtual TEM laboratory was easy, and the text in the virtual TEM laboratory was clear. They thought the verbal prompts in the virtual TEM laboratory were simple and easy to understand, and its operation was intuitive. They felt the visual design of the virtual TEM laboratory was delightful and consistent, and it runs smoothly. The statistical results revealed the average score of “Interface Design” is 4.36 for the experimental group A and is 3.97 for the experimental group B. According to the results of Levene’s test, the significance P for three questions regarding interface design is lower than the standard of significance (0.05) and thus there are distinct differences in these evaluation items. It is inferred according to the fact that the high school students were less familiar with the operation of tablet PCs and thus gave a lower score for interface design.

Operating experiences

This section investigates users’ operating experiences. Most students felt the virtual TEM laboratory helped them understand the functions of TEM and the nanostructures of materials. They would like to learn more about crystal structures using the virtual TEM laboratory. They had actively completed the tasks, taken the test, and clicked on the keywords to learn more about the TEM principles. After using the virtual TEM laboratory, they became more interested in nanostructure analysis. The completion of all tasks gave them a great sense of achievement, so they would like to use the virtual TEM laboratory as an interactive teaching material. The statistical results revealed that the average score of “Operating Experiences” is 4.17 for the experimental group A and is 4.13 for the experimental group B. According to the results of Levene’s test, there is no significant difference for each evaluation item in this section.

Open-ended questionnaire

After the teaching experiment, the control group was asked to use the virtual TEM laboratory for 30 min and filled out an open-ended questionnaire about the difference between the instructional video and the virtual TEM laboratory. The majority of students thought both the instructional video and the virtual TEM laboratory provided them with a very clear introduction about the principles and operating procedures of TEM. However, the virtual TEM laboratory gave them the sense of operating a real TEM, and it also provided additional explanations, information, and the online test for evaluation. Basically, using the virtual TEM was easier and less expensive than using a real TEM, so they would not have to worry about the damage of equipment and the difficulty of preparing samples. Besides, it was easy to obtain the experimental results and see the crystal structures of different samples. Compared with watching the instructional video, most students believed that it was easier to learn the knowledge in nanostructure analysis by using the virtual TEM laboratory.

Conclusions

Because nanostructures are extremely small and cannot be seen with the naked eye, it is necessary to use a high-resolution microscope to observe them. The resolution of TEM is significantly higher than that of light microscopes, so it can be used to examine the very fine detail of materials. The TEM can also be used as a diffractometer to obtain the diffraction patterns of materials for analysis of their 3D crystal structures. However, the equipment is very expensive, and the users must be familiar with the operational steps to avoid damaging it. For ordinary people to learn about the nanostructures of certain materials, they can only search for images on the Internet or go to the library to look for the related images in books. Acting in coordination with the NNTP promoted by NSC of Taiwan, this study developed a virtual TEM laboratory for operation on mobile devices to help students learn about using the TEM for the analysis of nanostructures. Furthermore, a teaching experiment was conducted to investigate the learning effectiveness and attitudes of students after using the virtual TEM laboratory. The experimental results revealed that: (1) the learning achievement of using the virtual TEM laboratory was significantly higher than that of using the instructional video, indicating that the interactive operation under a virtual environment could help improve students’ learning; (2) they gave positive feedback about the learning contents, interface design, and operating experiences after using the system, showing that it was useful to learn the TEM knowledge with the virtual TEM laboratory. Furthermore, after the teaching experiment, the students became more interested in exploring the nanostructures of materials.

This study developed a virtual TEM laboratory to solve the teaching difficulties of using expensive and complicated equipment such as the TEM for learning the operating procedure in analyzing materials’ 3D crystal structures. It provides the knowledge related to nanotechnology by simulated learning situations, allowing students to operate the TEM in a virtual laboratory to conduct some experiments. In addition to becoming familiar with the principles and operating procedures of TEM, students can also enhance their understanding of nanotechnology and the related concepts. The use of virtual TEM laboratory is not limited by time or space, and the 3D visual effects and highly interactive design make learning more interesting and effective. As a result, it is a suitable assistant tool for learning nanotechnology in high schools and colleges.
